data.title: QOTSA To Spend Spring On The Road
data.meta_description: Hard rock outfit Queens Of The Stone Age has confirmed an extensive slate of tour dates that will take the band to the Far East, Down Under, and across the U.
data.text:
Hard rock outfit Queens Of The Stone Age has confirmed an extensive slate of tour dates that will take the band to the Far East, Down Under, and across the U.S. Things get underway tonight (Jan. 10) in Fukuoka, Japan, to be followed by a previously announced stint on the annual Big Day Out tour of Australia and New Zealand. U.S. dates begin Feb. 22 in Las Vegas and wrap March 24 in Norfolk, Va.

The group is touring in support of its second Interscope album “Songs for the Deaf,” which is No. 51 in its 19th week on The Billboard 200. The single “No One Knows” is No. 3 on Billboard’s Modern Rock Tracks chart and No. 14 on the Mainstream Rock Tracks tally.

Earlier this week, the song was nominated for a best hard performance Grammy, battling such competition as the Foo Fighters’ “All My Life,” Godsmack’s “I Stand Alone,” P.O.D.’s “Youth of the Nation,” and System Of A Down’s “Aerials.”

In the midst of the upcoming tour, QOTSA will perform Jan. 18 on the Fox show “MADtv.” During the three-week break between its last Big Day Out show and the Vegas U.S. tour opener, the members of Queens plan to record the ninth installment of the “Desert Sessions” CD series, which has previously featured guest shots by Screaming Trees frontman (and current QOTSA member) Mark Lanegan, Soundgarden bassist Ben Shepherd, Dwarves vocalist Blag Jesus, and Monster Magnet/Wellwater Conspiracy principal John McBain, among others. The album will be released by Queens guitarist Josh Homme’s Rekords Rekords imprint.

Here are Queens Of The Stone Age’s tour dates:

Jan. 10: Fukuoka, Japan (Crossing Hall)

Jan. 11: Osaka, Japan (On Air Osaka)

Jan. 13: Nagoya, Japan (Club Quattro)

Jan. 14: Tokyo (Akasaka Blitz)

Jan. 17: Auckland (Ericcson Stadium)

Jan. 19: Gold Coast, Australia (Parklands)

Jan. 24: Sydney (Enmore Theatre)

Jan. 25: Sydney (Olympic Park Showgrounds)

Jan. 27: Melbourne (Royal Melbourne Showgrounds)

Jan. 31: Adelaide, Australia (RA&HS Showgrounds)

Feb. 2: Perth, Australia (Claremont Showgrounds)

Feb. 22: Las Vegas (the Joint)

Feb. 25: Anaheim, Calif. (the Grove)

Feb. 26: Ventura, Calif. (Ventura Theatre)

Feb. 28: La Jolla, Calif. (RIMAC Arena)

March 1: Tucson, Ariz. (Rialto)

March 4: El Paso, Texas (XCape)

March 5: Albuquerque, N.M. (Sunshine Theatre)

March 6: Lubbock, Texas (West Texas Canyon Amphitheatre)

March 8: Oklahoma City, Okla. (Diamond Ballroom)

March 9: Tulsa, Okla. (Cain’s Ballroom)

March 10: Fort Worth, Texas (Ridglea Theatre)

March 11: San Antonio, Texas (Sunset Station)

March 13: New Orleans (House of Blues)

March 14: Memphis (New Daisy Theatre)

March 17: Jacksonville, Fla. (Marquee Theatre)

March 18: Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (Culture Room)

March 19: Tampa, Fla. (Twilight)

March 21: Orlando, Fla. (Hard Rock Live)

March 22: Myrtle Beach, S.C. (House of Blues)

March 23: Raleigh, N.C. (Lincoln Theatre)

March 24: Norfolk, Va. (NorVa)
